1→import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2
     2→import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     3→import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4→
     5→open Finset Classical
     6→
     7→/--
     8→The number of distinct positive distances determined by a finite point set A in ℝ².
     9→-/
    10→noncomputable def numDistinctDistances (A : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))) : ℕ :=
    11→  ((A ×ˢ A).filter (fun pq => pq.1 ≠ pq.2)).image (fun pq => dist pq.1 pq.2) |>.card
    12→
    13→/--
    14→Two finite point sets in ℝ² are similar if there exists a map f : ℝ² → ℝ² that
    15→scales all distances by the same positive constant r and maps one set onto the other.
    16→-/
    17→def AreSimilar (A B : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))) : Prop :=
    18→  ∃ (f : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2) → EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) (r : ℝ),
    19→    r > 0 ∧
    20→    (∀ x y : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2), dist (f x) (f y) = r * dist x y) ∧
    21→    (∀ a, a ∈ A → f a ∈ B) ∧
    22→    (∀ b, b ∈ B → ∃ a ∈ A, f a = b)
    23→
    24→/--
    25→Erdős Problem #91:
    26→For sufficiently large n, if A ⊂ ℝ² has |A| = n and minimises the number of
    27→distinct distances, then there exists another minimiser A' of the same cardinality
    28→that is not similar to A. In other words, there are at least two non-similar
    29→sets that minimise the number of distinct distances.
    30→-/
    31→theorem erdos_problem_91 :
    32→    ∃ N : ℕ, ∀ n : ℕ, N ≤ n →
    33→    ∀ A : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)),
    34→      A.card = n →
    35→      (∀ B : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)), B.card = n →
    36→        numDistinctDistances A ≤ numDistinctDistances B) →
    37→      ∃ A' : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)),

    39→        (∀ B : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)), B.card = n →
    40→          numDistinctDistances A' ≤ numDistinctDistances B) ∧
    41→        ¬ AreSimilar A A' :=

1→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
     2→import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Aleph
     3→
     4→open Cardinal SimpleGraph
     5→
     6→noncomputable section
     7→
     8→namespace Erdos1174
     9→
    10→/-!
    11→# Erdős Problem #1174
    12→
    13→Does there exist a graph G with no K_4 such that every edge colouring of G
    14→with countably many colours contains a monochromatic K_3?
    15→
    16→Does there exist a graph G with no K_{ℵ_1} such that every edge colouring of G
    17→with countably many colours contains a monochromatic K_{ℵ_0}?
    18→
    19→A problem of Erdős and Hajnal. Shelah proved that a graph with either property
    20→can consistently exist.
    21→
    22→Tags: set theory, ramsey theory
    23→-/
    24→
    25→/--
    26→Erdős Problem #1174, Part 1 [Va99, 7.91]:
    27→
    28→Does there exist a graph G with no K_4 (no 4-clique) such that for every
    29→edge colouring of G with countably many colours (ℕ), some monochromatic K_3
    30→(a 3-clique whose three edges all receive the same colour) exists in G?
    31→
    32→This is an open problem of Erdős and Hajnal. Shelah proved that such a graph
    33→can consistently exist (i.e., its existence is consistent with ZFC).
    34→-/
    35→theorem erdos_problem_1174a :
    36→    ∃ (V : Type) (G : SimpleGraph V),
    37→      (∀ S : Finset V, ¬G.IsNClique 4 S) ∧
    38→      ∀ (col : V → V → ℕ), (∀ u v : V, col u v = col v u) →
    39→        ∃ (S : Finset V) (c : ℕ), G.IsNClique 3 S ∧
    40→          ∀ u ∈ S, ∀ v ∈ S, u ≠ v → col u v = c :=
    41→  sorry
    42→
    43→/--
    44→Erdős Problem #1174, Part 2 [Va99, 7.91]:
    45→
    46→Does there exist a graph G with no K_{ℵ_1} (no clique of cardinality ≥ ℵ_1)
    47→such that for every edge colouring of G with countably many colours (ℕ), some
    48→monochromatic K_{ℵ_0} exists — that is, a clique of cardinality ≥ ℵ_0 whose
    49→edges all receive the same colour?
    50→
    51→This is an open problem of Erdős and Hajnal. Shelah proved that such a graph
    52→can consistently exist (i.e., its existence is consistent with ZFC).
    53→-/
    54→theorem erdos_problem_1174b :
    55→    ∃ (V : Type) (G : SimpleGraph V),
    56→      (¬∃ S : Set V, aleph 1 ≤ Cardinal.mk ↥S ∧ G.IsClique S) ∧
    57→      ∀ (col : V → V → ℕ), (∀ u v : V, col u v = col v u) →
    58→        ∃ (S : Set V) (c : ℕ), aleph 0 ≤ Cardinal.mk ↥S ∧ G.IsClique S ∧
    59→          ∀ u ∈ S, ∀ v ∈ S, u ≠ v → col u v = c :=
    60→  sorry
    61→
    62→end Erdos1174
    63→
    64→end
    65→

1→import Mathlib.Data.Real.Sqrt
     2→import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Lattice
     3→
     4→noncomputable section
     5→
     6→/-!
     7→# Erdős Problem #724
     8→
     9→Let f(n) be the maximum number of mutually orthogonal Latin squares of order n.
    10→Is it true that f(n) ≫ n^{1/2}?
    11→
    12→A Latin square of order n is an n × n array filled with n symbols such that
    13→each symbol occurs exactly once in each row and each column.
    14→
    15→Two Latin squares L₁, L₂ of order n are orthogonal if the map
    16→(i, j) ↦ (L₁(i,j), L₂(i,j)) is injective (equivalently bijective) on
    17→Fin n × Fin n, i.e., every ordered pair of symbols occurs exactly once
    18→when the squares are superimposed.
    19→
    20→Chowla, Erdős, and Straus [CES60] proved f(n) ≫ n^{1/91}.
    21→Wilson [Wi74] improved this to f(n) ≫ n^{1/17}.
    22→Beth [Be83c] improved this to f(n) ≫ n^{1/14.8}.
    23→-/
    24→
    25→/-- A Latin square of order n: a function `Fin n → Fin n → Fin n` such that
    26→    each row and each column is a bijection. -/
    27→def IsLatinSquare {n : ℕ} (L : Fin n → Fin n → Fin n) : Prop :=
    28→  (∀ i : Fin n, Function.Bijective (L i)) ∧
    29→  (∀ j : Fin n, Function.Bijective (fun i => L i j))
    30→
    31→/-- Two Latin squares of order n are orthogonal if the map
    32→    `(i, j) ↦ (L₁ i j, L₂ i j)` is injective on `Fin n × Fin n`. -/
    33→def AreOrthogonalLatinSquares {n : ℕ} (L₁ L₂ : Fin n → Fin n → Fin n) : Prop :=
    34→  Function.Injective (fun p : Fin n × Fin n => (L₁ p.1 p.2, L₂ p.1 p.2))
    35→
    36→/-- A family of k Latin squares of order n is mutually orthogonal if each
    37→    is a Latin square and every distinct pair is orthogonal. -/
    38→def IsMOLS {n k : ℕ} (L : Fin k → Fin n → Fin n → Fin n) : Prop :=
    39→  (∀ i : Fin k, IsLatinSquare (L i)) ∧
    40→  (∀ i j : Fin k, i ≠ j → AreOrthogonalLatinSquares (L i) (L j))
    41→
    42→/-- The maximum number of mutually orthogonal Latin squares of order n. -/
    43→noncomputable def maxMOLS (n : ℕ) : ℕ :=
    44→  sSup {k : ℕ | ∃ L : Fin k → Fin n → Fin n → Fin n, IsMOLS L}
    45→
    46→/--
    47→Erdős Problem #724 [Er81]:
    48→
    49→Let f(n) be the maximum number of mutually orthogonal Latin squares of order n.
    50→Is it true that f(n) ≫ n^{1/2}?
    51→
    52→Formalized as: there exists a constant C > 0 such that for all sufficiently
    53→large n, maxMOLS(n) ≥ C · √n.
    54→-/
    55→theorem erdos_problem_724 :
    56→    ∃ C : ℝ, C > 0 ∧ ∃ N₀ : ℕ, ∀ n : ℕ, n ≥ N₀ →
    57→      (maxMOLS n : ℝ) ≥ C * Real.sqrt (n : ℝ) :=
    58→  sorry
    59→
    60→end
    61→

1→import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Prime.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     3→import Mathlib.Topology.Order.Basic
     4→import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Basic
     5→import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     6→import Mathlib.Order.Interval.Finset.Nat
     7→
     8→open Finset Filter Classical
     9→
    10→noncomputable section
    11→
    12→/-!
    13→# Erdős Problem #459
    14→
    15→Let $f(u)$ be the largest $v$ such that no $m \in (u,v)$ is composed entirely
    16→of primes dividing $uv$. Equivalently, $f(u)$ is the smallest integer $v > u$
    17→such that every prime factor of $v$ divides $u$.
    18→
    19→Trivially $u + 2 \leq f(u) \leq u^2$.
    20→
    21→Cambie showed:
    22→- $f(p) = p^2$ for every prime $p$
    23→- $f(u) = u + 2$ whenever $u = 2^k - 2$ for $k \geq 2$
    24→- $f(n) = (1 + o(1))n$ for almost all $n$
    25→
    26→This problem is marked as solved.
    27→-/
    28→
    29→/-- `erdos459_f u` is the smallest `v > u` such that every prime factor
    30→    of `v` divides `u`. -/
    31→noncomputable def erdos459_f (u : ℕ) : ℕ :=
    32→  sInf {v : ℕ | u < v ∧ ∀ p : ℕ, Nat.Prime p → p ∣ v → p ∣ u}
    33→
    34→/--
    35→Erdős Problem #459 (Lower bound) [ErGr80, p.91]:
    36→
    37→For all u ≥ 2, f(u) ≥ u + 2.
    38→-/
    39→theorem erdos_problem_459_lower_bound (u : ℕ) (hu : 2 ≤ u) :
    40→    u + 2 ≤ erdos459_f u :=
    41→  sorry
    42→
    43→/--
    44→Erdős Problem #459 (Upper bound) [ErGr80, p.91]:
    45→
    46→For all u ≥ 2, f(u) ≤ u².
    47→-/
    48→theorem erdos_problem_459_upper_bound (u : ℕ) (hu : 2 ≤ u) :
    49→    erdos459_f u ≤ u ^ 2 :=
    50→  sorry
    51→
    52→/--
    53→Erdős Problem #459 (Prime case, Cambie):
    54→
    55→For every prime p, f(p) = p².
    56→-/
    57→theorem erdos_problem_459_prime (p : ℕ) (hp : Nat.Prime p) :
    58→    erdos459_f p = p ^ 2 :=
    59→  sorry
    60→
    61→/--
    62→Erdős Problem #459 (Almost all, Cambie):
    63→
    64→f(n) = (1 + o(1))n for almost all n, i.e., for every ε > 0, the density
    65→of {n : f(n) > (1 + ε)n} tends to 0.
    66→-/
    67→theorem erdos_problem_459_almost_all (ε : ℝ) (hε : 0 < ε) :
    68→    Tendsto (fun x : ℕ =>
    69→      (((Finset.Icc 1 x).filter (fun n =>
    70→        (erdos459_f n : ℝ) > (1 + ε) * (n : ℝ))).card : ℝ) / (x : ℝ))
    71→      atTop (nhds 0) :=
    72→  sorry
    73→
    74→end
    75→

1→import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Totient
     2→import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Prime.Basic
     3→import Mathlib.Data.Nat.ModEq
     4→import Mathlib.Data.Set.Finite.Basic
     5→import Mathlib.Order.Filter.AtTopBot.Basic
     6→import Mathlib.Topology.Order.Basic
     7→import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Basic
     8→import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     9→import Mathlib.Order.Interval.Finset.Nat
    10→
    11→open Finset Filter Classical
    12→
    13→noncomputable section
    14→
    15→/-!
    16→# Erdős Problem #456
    17→
    18→Let $p_n$ be the smallest prime $\equiv 1 \pmod{n}$ and let $m_n$ be the
    19→smallest positive integer such that $n \mid \phi(m_n)$.
    20→
    21→1. Is it true that $m_n < p_n$ for almost all $n$?
    22→2. Does $p_n / m_n \to \infty$ for almost all $n$?
    23→3. Are there infinitely many primes $p$ such that $p - 1$ is the only $n$
    24→   for which $m_n = p$?
    25→
    26→Linnik's theorem implies that $p_n \leq n^{O(1)}$. It is trivial that
    27→$m_n \leq p_n$ always. If $n = q - 1$ for some prime $q$ then $m_n = p_n$.
    28→-/
    29→
    30→/-- The smallest prime congruent to 1 modulo n. -/
    31→noncomputable def smallestPrimeCong1 (n : ℕ) : ℕ :=
    32→  sInf {p : ℕ | Nat.Prime p ∧ p ≡ 1 [MOD n]}
    33→
    34→/-- The smallest positive integer m such that n ∣ φ(m). -/
    35→noncomputable def smallestTotientDiv (n : ℕ) : ℕ :=
    36→  sInf {m : ℕ | 0 < m ∧ n ∣ Nat.totient m}
    37→
    38→/--
    39→Erdős Problem #456, Part 1 [Er79e, p.80]:
    40→
    41→Is it true that $m_n < p_n$ for almost all $n$?
    42→
    43→Formalized as: the density of $\{n : m_n \geq p_n\}$ is 0, i.e., the
    44→proportion of $n \leq x$ for which $p_n \leq m_n$ tends to 0 as $x \to \infty$.
    45→-/
    46→theorem erdos_problem_456_part1 :
    47→    Tendsto (fun x : ℕ =>
    48→      (((Finset.Icc 1 x).filter (fun n =>
    49→        smallestPrimeCong1 n ≤ smallestTotientDiv n)).card : ℝ) / (x : ℝ))
    50→      atTop (nhds 0) :=
    51→  sorry
    52→
    53→/--
    54→Erdős Problem #456, Part 2 [Er79e, p.80]:
    55→
    56→Does $p_n / m_n \to \infty$ for almost all $n$?
    57→
    58→Formalized as: for every $C > 0$, the density of $\{n : p_n \leq C \cdot m_n\}$
    59→is 0.
    60→-/
    61→theorem erdos_problem_456_part2 :
    62→    ∀ C : ℝ, 0 < C →
    63→      Tendsto (fun x : ℕ =>
    64→        (((Finset.Icc 1 x).filter (fun n =>
    65→          (smallestPrimeCong1 n : ℝ) ≤ C * (smallestTotientDiv n : ℝ))).card : ℝ) / (x : ℝ))
    66→        atTop (nhds 0) :=
    67→  sorry
    68→
    69→/--
    70→Erdős Problem #456, Part 3 [ErGr80, p.91]:
    71→
    72→Are there infinitely many primes $p$ such that $p - 1$ is the only $n$ for
    73→which $m_n = p$?
    74→-/
    75→theorem erdos_problem_456_part3 :
    76→    Set.Infinite {p : ℕ | Nat.Prime p ∧
    77→      smallestTotientDiv (p - 1) = p ∧
    78→      ∀ n : ℕ, smallestTotientDiv n = p → n = p - 1} :=
    79→  sorry
    80→
    81→end
    82→

1→import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Powerset
     3→import Mathlib.Data.Rat.Defs
     4→import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic
     5→import Mathlib.Order.Interval.Finset.Nat
     6→import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Basic
     7→import Mathlib.Order.Filter.Basic
     8→import Mathlib.Topology.Order.Basic
     9→
    10→open Finset BigOperators Filter Real
    11→
    12→/-!
    13→# Erdős Problem #297
    14→
    15→Let N ≥ 1. How many A ⊆ {1, ..., N} are there such that ∑_{n ∈ A} 1/n = 1?
    16→
    17→It was not even known for a long time whether this is 2^{cN} for some c < 1 or
    18→2^{(1+o(1))N}. In fact the former is true, and the correct value of c is now known.
    19→
    20→Steinerberger [St24] proved the count is at most 2^{0.93N}. Independently,
    21→Liu and Sawhney [LiSa24] gave both upper and lower bounds, proving that the
    22→count is 2^{(0.91...+o(1))N}, where 0.91... is an explicit number defined as
    23→the solution to a certain integral equation. Again independently, the same
    24→asymptotic was proved by Conlon–Fox–He–Mubayi–Pham–Suk–Verstraëte [CFHMPSV24].
    25→-/
    26→
    27→/-- Count of subsets A ⊆ {1, ..., N} such that ∑_{n ∈ A} 1/n = 1. -/
    28→noncomputable def unitFractionSubsetCount (N : ℕ) : ℕ :=
    29→  ((Finset.Icc 1 N).powerset.filter fun (A : Finset ℕ) =>
    30→    (A.sum fun n => (1 : ℚ) / (n : ℚ)) = 1).card
    31→
    32→/--
    33→Erdős Problem #297 [ErGr80, p.36] — SOLVED
    34→
    35→There exists a constant c ∈ (0, 1) such that the number of subsets
    36→A ⊆ {1, ..., N} with ∑_{n ∈ A} 1/n = 1 is 2^{(c+o(1))N}.
    37→
    38→Equivalently, log₂(count(N)) / N → c as N → ∞.
    39→-/
    40→theorem erdos_problem_297 :
    41→    ∃ c : ℝ, 0 < c ∧ c < 1 ∧
    42→      Tendsto (fun N : ℕ =>
    43→        Real.log (unitFractionSubsetCount N : ℝ) / (Real.log 2 * (N : ℝ)))
    44→        atTop (nhds c) :=
    45→  sorry
    46→

1→/-

     3→

    14→limitations under the License.
    15→-/
    16→
    17→import FormalConjectures.Util.ProblemImports
    18→
    19→/-!
    20→# Erdős Problem 86
    21→
    22→*Reference:* [erdosproblems.com/86](https://www.erdosproblems.com/86)
    23→
    24→Let $Q_n$ be the $n$-dimensional hypercube graph (so that $Q_n$ has $2^n$ vertices
    25→and $n \cdot 2^{n-1}$ edges). Is it true that every subgraph of $Q_n$ with
    26→$\geq (\frac{1}{2} + o(1)) n \cdot 2^{n-1}$ many edges contains a $C_4$?
    27→
    28→Equivalently, let $f(n)$ be the maximum number of edges in a subgraph of $Q_n$
    29→without a $C_4$. The conjecture is that $f(n) \leq (\frac{1}{2} + o(1)) n \cdot 2^{n-1}$.
    30→
    31→Erdős [Er91] showed that $f(n) \geq (\frac{1}{2} + c/n) n \cdot 2^{n-1}$ for some
    32→constant $c > 0$. Brass, Harborth, and Nienborg [BHN95] improved the lower bound to
    33→$f(n) \geq (\frac{1}{2} + c/\sqrt{n}) n \cdot 2^{n-1}$.
    34→
    35→Balogh, Hu, Lidicky, and Liu [BHLL14] proved $f(n) \leq 0.6068 \cdot n \cdot 2^{n-1}$.
    36→This was improved to $\leq 0.60318 \cdot n \cdot 2^{n-1}$ by Baber [Ba12b].
    37→
    38→[Er90][Er91][Er92b][Er93][Er94b][Er95][Er97f]
    39→-/
    40→
    41→open SimpleGraph Finset
    42→
    43→namespace Erdos86
    44→
    45→/-- The $n$-dimensional hypercube graph $Q_n$. Vertices are functions
    46→$\operatorname{Fin} n \to \operatorname{Bool}$, and two vertices are adjacent iff they differ
    47→in exactly one coordinate. -/
    48→noncomputable def hypercubeGraph (n : ℕ) : SimpleGraph (Fin n → Bool) where
    49→  Adj u v := u ≠ v ∧ (Finset.univ.filter (fun i => u i ≠ v i)).card = 1
    50→  symm u v := by
    51→    rintro ⟨hne, hcard⟩
    52→    refine ⟨hne.symm, ?_⟩
    53→    have heq : (Finset.univ.filter fun i => v i ≠ u i) =
    54→               (Finset.univ.filter fun i => u i ≠ v i) :=
    55→      Finset.filter_congr (fun i _ => ne_comm)
    56→    rw [heq]
    57→    exact hcard
    58→  loopless := ⟨fun v ⟨hne, _⟩ => hne rfl⟩
    59→
    60→/-- The cycle graph $C_m$ on $m$ vertices ($m \geq 3$). Vertex $i$ is adjacent to vertex
    61→$i + 1 \pmod{m}$ and vertex $i - 1 \pmod{m}$. -/
    62→def cycleGraph (m : ℕ) (_ : m ≥ 3) : SimpleGraph (Fin m) where
    63→  Adj i j := i ≠ j ∧ (j.val = (i.val + 1) % m ∨ i.val = (j.val + 1) % m)
    64→  symm := fun _ _ ⟨hne, h⟩ => ⟨hne.symm, h.elim Or.inr Or.inl⟩
    65→  loopless := ⟨fun _ ⟨h, _⟩ => h rfl⟩
    66→
    67→/--
    68→Erdős Problem 86 [Er90][Er91][Er92b][Er93][Er94b][Er95][Er97f]:
    69→
    70→Is it true that for every $\varepsilon > 0$, if $n$ is sufficiently large, every subgraph of
    71→$Q_n$ with at least $(\frac{1}{2} + \varepsilon) \cdot n \cdot 2^{n-1}$ edges contains a $C_4$?
    72→-/
    73→@[category research open, AMS 5]
    74→theorem erdos_86 : answer(sorry) ↔
    75→    ∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 →
    76→    ∃ N₀ : ℕ, ∀ n : ℕ, n ≥ N₀ →
    77→    ∀ H : SimpleGraph (Fin n → Bool),
    78→      (∀ u v : Fin n → Bool, H.Adj u v → (hypercubeGraph n).Adj u v) →
    79→      (↑(H.edgeFinset.card) : ℝ) ≥ (1 / 2 + ε) * ↑n * (2 : ℝ) ^ (n - 1 : ℕ) →
    80→      ∃ f : Fin 4 → (Fin n → Bool), Function.Injective f ∧
    81→        ∀ i j, (cycleGraph 4 (by omega)).Adj i j → H.Adj (f i) (f j) := by
    82→  sorry
    83→
    84→end Erdos86
    85→

    14→limitations under the License.

    16→
    17→import FormalConjectures.Util.ProblemImports
    18→
    19→/-!
    20→# Erdős Problem 72
    21→
    22→*Reference:* [erdosproblems.com/72](https://www.erdosproblems.com/72)
    23→
    24→[Ve05] Verstraëte, J., *A note on vertex-disjoint cycles*, Combinatorics, Probability and
    25→Computing 14 (2005), 127-143.
    26→
    27→[LiMo20] Liu, H. and Montgomery, R., *A solution to Erdős and Hajnal's odd cycle problem*,
    28→Journal of the American Mathematical Society 36 (2023), 1191-1234.
    29→-/
    30→
    31→open SimpleGraph
    32→
    33→namespace Erdos72
    34→
    35→/--
    36→A set $A \subseteq \mathbb{N}$ has natural density zero: for every $\varepsilon > 0$, for all
    37→sufficiently large $n$, $|A \cap \{0, \ldots, n\}| \leq \varepsilon \cdot n$.
    38→-/
    39→def HasDensityZero (A : Set ℕ) : Prop :=
    40→  ∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 → ∃ N : ℕ, ∀ n : ℕ, n ≥ N →
    41→    (Set.ncard (A ∩ Set.Iic n) : ℝ) ≤ ε * (n : ℝ)
    42→
    43→/--
    44→Is there a set $A \subset \mathbb{N}$ of density $0$ and a constant $c > 0$ such that every graph on
    45→sufficiently many vertices with average degree $\geq c$ contains a cycle whose length is in $A$?
    46→
    47→Solved affirmatively by Verstraëte [Ve05] (non-constructive proof).
    48→Liu and Montgomery [LiMo20] proved this holds even when $A$ is the set of powers of $2$.
    49→-/
    50→@[category research solved, AMS 5]
    51→theorem erdos_72 :
    52→    ∃ (A : Set ℕ), HasDensityZero A ∧
    53→    ∃ (c : ℝ), c > 0 ∧
    54→    ∃ (N₀ : ℕ), ∀ (n : ℕ), n ≥ N₀ →
    55→      ∀ (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)) (hd : DecidableRel G.Adj),
    56→        haveI := hd
    57→        2 * (G.edgeFinset.card : ℝ) ≥ c * (n : ℝ) →
    58→        ∃ (k : ℕ), k ∈ A ∧ ∃ (v : Fin n), ∃ (p : G.Walk v v), p.IsCycle ∧ p.length = k := by
    59→  sorry
    60→
    61→end Erdos72
    62→

    14→limitations under the License.
    15→-/
    16→
    17→import FormalConjectures.Util.ProblemImports
    18→
    19→/-!
    20→# Erdős Problem 65
    21→
    22→*Reference:* [erdosproblems.com/65](https://www.erdosproblems.com/65)
    23→
    24→[GKS84] Gyárfás, A., Komlós, J., and Szemerédi, E., *On the distribution of cycle lengths in
    25→graphs*, J. Graph Theory 8 (1984), 441–462.
    26→
    27→[LiMo20] Liu, H. and Montgomery, R., *A solution to Erdős and Hajnal's odd cycle problem*,
    28→J. Amer. Math. Soc. 36 (2023), 1191–1234.
    29→-/
    30→
    31→open SimpleGraph Finset
    32→
    33→namespace Erdos65
    34→
    35→/-- The complete bipartite graph $K_{a,b}$ on `Fin (a + b)`, where vertices
    36→$\{0, \ldots, a-1\}$ form one part and $\{a, \ldots, a+b-1\}$ form the other. -/
    37→def completeBipartiteGraph65 (a b : ℕ) : SimpleGraph (Fin (a + b)) where
    38→  Adj u v := (u.val < a ∧ a ≤ v.val) ∨ (a ≤ u.val ∧ v.val < a)
    39→  symm u v h := by
    40→    rcases h with ⟨hu, hv⟩ | ⟨hu, hv⟩
    41→    · exact Or.inr ⟨hv, hu⟩
    42→    · exact Or.inl ⟨hv, hu⟩
    43→  loopless := ⟨fun v h => by rcases h with ⟨h1, h2⟩ | ⟨h1, h2⟩ <;> omega⟩
    44→
    45→/--
    46→Erdős Problem #65 (Erdős–Hajnal) [GKS84] [LiMo20]:
    47→Let $G$ be a graph with $n$ vertices and $kn$ edges, and let $a_1 < a_2 < \cdots$ be the
    48→distinct lengths of cycles in $G$. Is it true that $\sum 1/a_i \gg \log k$? Is the sum
    49→$\sum 1/a_i$ minimised when $G$ is a complete bipartite graph?
    50→
    51→The first question was proved by Gyárfás, Komlós, and Szemerédi [GKS84].
    52→Liu and Montgomery [LiMo20] proved the asymptotically sharp lower bound
    53→$\geq (1/2 - o(1)) \log k$.
    54→
    55→The remaining open question is formalized below: for any graph $G$ on $n$ vertices whose edge
    56→count equals $a \cdot b$ for some partition $a + b = n$, the sum of reciprocals of distinct cycle
    57→lengths of $G$ is at least the corresponding sum for the complete bipartite graph $K_{a,b}$.
    58→-/
    59→@[category research open, AMS 5]
    60→theorem erdos_65 {n : ℕ}
    61→    (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n))
    62→    (a b : ℕ) (hab : a + b = n) [DecidableRel G.Adj]
    63→    (hedge : a * b = G.edgeFinset.card)
    64→    (T_G : Finset ℕ)
    65→    (hT_sub : ∀ m ∈ T_G, ∃ v : Fin n, ∃ p : G.Walk v v, p.IsCycle ∧ p.length = m)
    66→    (hT_sup : ∀ m : ℕ, (∃ v : Fin n, ∃ p : G.Walk v v, p.IsCycle ∧ p.length = m) → m ∈ T_G) :
    67→    ∃ (T_K : Finset ℕ),
    68→      (∀ m ∈ T_K, ∃ v : Fin (a + b),
    69→        ∃ p : (completeBipartiteGraph65 a b).Walk v v, p.IsCycle ∧ p.length = m) ∧
    70→      (∀ m : ℕ, (∃ v : Fin (a + b),
    71→        ∃ p : (completeBipartiteGraph65 a b).Walk v v, p.IsCycle ∧ p.length = m) → m ∈ T_K) ∧
    72→      ∑ m ∈ T_K, (1 / (m : ℝ)) ≤ ∑ m ∈ T_G, (1 / (m : ℝ)) := by
    73→  sorry
    74→
    75→end Erdos65
    76→

1→import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2
     2→import Mathlib.Topology.Connected.Basic
     3→import Mathlib.Topology.Homeomorph.Defs
     4→import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Basic
     5→import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Continuum
     6→
     7→open Set Cardinal Topology
     8→
     9→noncomputable section
    10→
    11→/-!
    12→# Erdős Problem #910
    13→
    14→Does every connected set in ℝⁿ contain a connected subset which is not a point
    15→and not homeomorphic to the original set?
    16→
    17→If n ≥ 2, does every connected set in ℝⁿ contain more than 2^ℵ₀ many connected
    18→subsets?
    19→
    20→Asked by Erdős in the 1940s, who thought the answer to both questions is yes.
    21→The answer to both is in fact no, as shown by Rudin [Ru58] (conditional on the
    22→continuum hypothesis).
    23→
    24→Tags: topology
    25→-/
    26→
    27→/--
    28→Erdős Problem #910, Part 1 (disproved by Rudin [Ru58]):
    29→
    30→Every connected set in ℝⁿ contains a connected subset which is not a single
    31→point and not homeomorphic to the original set.
    32→-/
    33→theorem erdos_problem_910a (n : ℕ) (hn : n ≥ 1) :
    34→    ∀ (S : Set (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin n))),
    35→    IsConnected S →
    36→    ∃ (T : Set (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin n))),
    37→      T ⊆ S ∧ IsConnected T ∧ T.Nontrivial ∧
    38→      IsEmpty (Homeomorph T S) :=
    39→  sorry
    40→
    41→/--
    42→Erdős Problem #910, Part 2 (disproved by Rudin [Ru58]):
    43→
    44→If n ≥ 2, every connected set in ℝⁿ has more than 2^ℵ₀ many connected subsets.
    45→-/
    46→theorem erdos_problem_910b (n : ℕ) (hn : n ≥ 2) :
    47→    ∀ (S : Set (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin n))),
    48→    IsConnected S →
    49→    Cardinal.continuum < #{T : Set (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin n)) // T ⊆ S ∧ IsConnected T} :=
    50→  sorry
    51→
    52→end
    53→

1→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Lattice
     3→import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Finite
     4→
     5→open SimpleGraph
     6→
     7→noncomputable section
     8→
     9→/-!
    10→# Erdős Problem #911
    11→
    12→Let R̂(G) denote the size Ramsey number, the minimal number of edges m such
    13→that there is a graph H with m edges such that in any 2-colouring of the
    14→edges of H there is a monochromatic copy of G.
    15→
    16→Is there a function f such that f(x)/x → ∞ as x → ∞ such that, for all
    17→large C, if G is a graph with n vertices and e ≥ Cn edges then
    18→R̂(G) > f(C) · e?
    19→
    20→https://www.erdosproblems.com/911
    21→
    22→Tags: graph theory, ramsey theory
    23→-/
    24→
    25→/-- The size Ramsey number R̂(G): the minimum number of edges in a graph H
    26→    that is Ramsey for G.
    27→
    28→    A graph H on N vertices is Ramsey for G if every 2-coloring of the edges
    29→    of H (represented as a symmetric function c : Fin N → Fin N → Bool)
    30→    contains a monochromatic copy of G, i.e., an injective map f from the
    31→    vertices of G into Fin N that preserves adjacency in H and maps all
    32→    edges to the same color. -/
    33→noncomputable def sizeRamseyNumber {V : Type*} [Fintype V]
    34→    (G : SimpleGraph V) : ℕ :=
    35→  sInf {m : ℕ | ∃ (N : ℕ) (H : SimpleGraph (Fin N)),
    36→    Nat.card H.edgeSet = m ∧
    37→    ∀ (c : Fin N → Fin N → Bool),
    38→      (∀ i j, c i j = c j i) →
    39→      ∃ (b : Bool) (f : V → Fin N),
    40→        Function.Injective f ∧
    41→        (∀ u v, G.Adj u v → H.Adj (f u) (f v)) ∧
    42→        (∀ u v, G.Adj u v → c (f u) (f v) = b)}
    43→
    44→/--
    45→Erdős Problem #911 [Er82e, p.78]:
    46→
    47→There exists a function f : ℕ → ℕ with f(x)/x → ∞ as x → ∞ such that,
    48→for all sufficiently large C, if G is any graph with n vertices and at
    49→least C · n edges then R̂(G) > f(C) · |E(G)|.
    50→-/
    51→theorem erdos_problem_911 :
    52→    ∃ f : ℕ → ℕ,
    53→      -- f(x)/x → ∞ as x → ∞
    54→      (∀ M : ℕ, ∃ x₀ : ℕ, ∀ x : ℕ, x ≥ x₀ → f x ≥ M * x) ∧
    55→      -- For all large C, the bound holds
    56→      ∃ C₀ : ℕ, ∀ C : ℕ, C ≥ C₀ →
    57→        ∀ n : ℕ, ∀ G : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
    58→          Nat.card G.edgeSet ≥ C * n →
    59→          sizeRamseyNumber G > f C * Nat.card G.edgeSet :=
    60→  sorry
    61→
    62→end
    63→

1→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
     3→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.DegreeSum
     4→
     5→open SimpleGraph Finset
     6→
     7→noncomputable section
     8→
     9→/-!
    10→# Erdős Problem #914
    11→
    12→Let r ≥ 2 and m ≥ 1. Every graph with r·m vertices and minimum degree at
    13→least m·(r-1) contains m vertex disjoint copies of K_r.
    14→
    15→When r = 2 this follows from Dirac's theorem. Corrádi and Hajnal proved
    16→this when r = 3. Hajnal and Szemerédi proved this for all r ≥ 4.
    17→
    18→This is known as the Hajnal–Szemerédi theorem.
    19→
    20→https://www.erdosproblems.com/914
    21→
    22→Tags: graph theory
    23→-/
    24→
    25→/--
    26→Erdős Problem #914 (proved by Hajnal and Szemerédi [HaSz70]):
    27→
    28→Let r ≥ 2 and m ≥ 1. Every graph on r·m vertices with minimum degree at
    29→least m·(r-1) contains m vertex-disjoint copies of K_r (complete graphs
    30→on r vertices).
    31→-/
    32→theorem erdos_problem_914 (r m : ℕ) (hr : r ≥ 2) (hm : m ≥ 1)
    33→    (G : SimpleGraph (Fin (r * m))) [DecidableRel G.Adj]
    34→    (hdeg : ∀ v : Fin (r * m), G.degree v ≥ m * (r - 1)) :
    35→    ∃ S : Fin m → Finset (Fin (r * m)),
    36→      (∀ i, (S i).card = r) ∧
    37→      (∀ i, G.IsClique (S i : Set (Fin (r * m)))) ∧
    38→      (∀ i j, i ≠ j → Disjoint (S i) (S j)) :=
    39→  sorry
    40→
    41→end
    42→

1→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Finite
     3→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Walks.Basic
     4→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Paths
     5→import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Choose.Basic
     6→
     7→open SimpleGraph Finset
     8→
     9→noncomputable section
    10→
    11→/-!
    12→# Erdős Problem #915
    13→
    14→Let G be a graph with 1+n(m-1) vertices and 1+n·C(m,2) edges. Must G
    15→contain two vertices which are connected by m disjoint paths?
    16→
    17→A conjecture of Bollobás and Erdős [BoEr62]. It is unclear whether
    18→"disjoint" means edge-disjoint or (internally) vertex-disjoint. The
    19→above construction (n copies of K_m sharing a single vertex) is valid
    20→for either interpretation.
    21→
    22→The vertex-disjoint version was disproved by Leonard [Le73] for m = 5
    23→and by Mader [Ma73] for all m ≥ 6. The edge-disjoint version was
    24→confirmed (and strengthened) by Mader [Ma73].
    25→
    26→https://www.erdosproblems.com/915
    27→
    28→Tags: graph theory
    29→-/
    30→
    31→/-- Two vertices u, v in a simple graph G are connected by m internally
    32→    vertex-disjoint paths if there exist m paths from u to v such that
    33→    no internal vertex of one path appears as an internal vertex of another. -/
    34→def HasInternallyDisjointPaths {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V)
    35→    (u v : V) (m : ℕ) : Prop :=
    36→  ∃ (paths : Fin m → G.Walk u v),
    37→    (∀ i, (paths i).IsPath) ∧
    38→    (∀ i j, i ≠ j → ∀ w : V, w ≠ u → w ≠ v →
    39→      w ∈ (paths i).support → w ∉ (paths j).support)
    40→
    41→/--
    42→Erdős Problem #915 (Bollobás–Erdős conjecture [BoEr62]):
    43→
    44→Let G be a graph with 1 + n(m-1) vertices and at least 1 + n·C(m,2) edges.
    45→Then G contains two vertices connected by m internally vertex-disjoint paths.
    46→
    47→This was disproved by Leonard [Le73] for m = 5 and by Mader [Ma73] for all
    48→m ≥ 6. The edge-disjoint analogue was confirmed by Mader.
    49→-/
    50→theorem erdos_problem_915 (n m : ℕ) (hm : m ≥ 2)
    51→    (G : SimpleGraph (Fin (1 + n * (m - 1)))) [DecidableRel G.Adj]
    52→    (hedge : G.edgeFinset.card ≥ 1 + n * m.choose 2) :
    53→    ∃ u v : Fin (1 + n * (m - 1)), u ≠ v ∧
    54→      HasInternallyDisjointPaths G u v m :=
    55→  sorry
    56→
    57→end
    58→

1→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Finite
     3→
     4→open SimpleGraph Finset
     5→
     6→/-!
     7→# Erdős Problem #916
     8→
     9→Does every graph with n vertices and 2n-2 edges contain a cycle and another
    10→vertex adjacent to three vertices on the cycle?
    11→
    12→This would be a stronger form of Dirac's result [Di60] that every such graph
    13→contains a subgraph homeomorphic to K₄.
    14→
    15→The answer is yes, as proved by Thomassen [Th74].
    16→-/
    17→
    18→/--
    19→Erdős Problem #916 [Er67b]:
    20→
    21→Every simple graph with n vertices and at least 2n-2 edges contains a cycle C
    22→and a vertex v not on C that is adjacent to at least three vertices of C.
    23→
    24→A cycle of length m (m ≥ 3) is represented as an injective map
    25→`cycle : Fin m → Fin n` where consecutive vertices (including wrap-around)
    26→are adjacent.
    27→-/
    28→theorem erdos_problem_916 (n : ℕ) (hn : n ≥ 4)
    29→    (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)) [DecidableRel G.Adj]
    30→    (hedge : G.edgeFinset.card ≥ 2 * n - 2) :
    31→    ∃ (k : ℕ) (cycle : Fin (k + 3) → Fin n),
    32→      Function.Injective cycle ∧
    33→      (∀ i : Fin (k + 3), G.Adj (cycle i)
    34→        (cycle ⟨(i.val + 1) % (k + 3), Nat.mod_lt _ (by omega)⟩)) ∧
    35→      ∃ v : Fin n, v ∉ Set.range cycle ∧
    36→        ∃ (i j l : Fin (k + 3)), i ≠ j ∧ j ≠ l ∧ i ≠ l ∧
    37→          G.Adj v (cycle i) ∧ G.Adj v (cycle j) ∧ G.Adj v (cycle l) :=
    38→  sorry
    39→

1→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Coloring
     3→import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4→import Mathlib.Data.Set.Card
     5→
     6→open SimpleGraph
     7→
     8→/-!
     9→# Erdős Problem #917
    10→
    11→Let k ≥ 4 and f_k(n) be the largest number of edges in a graph on n vertices
    12→which has chromatic number k and is critical (i.e. deleting any edge reduces
    13→the chromatic number).
    14→
    15→Is it true that f_k(n) ≫_k n²?
    16→Is it true that f₆(n) ∼ n²/4?
    17→More generally, is it true that, for k ≥ 6,
    18→  f_k(n) ∼ (1/2)(1 - 1/⌊k/3⌋) n²?
    19→
    20→Toft [To70] proved that f_k(n) ≫_k n² for k ≥ 4.
    21→Stiebitz [St87] disproved the asymptotic for k ≢ 0 (mod 3).
    22→-/
    23→
    24→/--
    25→A simple graph G is k-critical if its chromatic number equals k and for every
    26→edge e, the graph obtained by deleting e has chromatic number strictly less
    27→than k.
    28→-/
    29→def SimpleGraph.IsCritical {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) (k : ℕ) : Prop :=
    30→  G.chromaticNumber = (k : ℕ∞) ∧
    31→  ∀ e ∈ G.edgeSet, (G.deleteEdges {e}).chromaticNumber < (k : ℕ∞)
    32→
    33→/--
    34→Erdős Problem #917, Part 1 [Er69b]:
    35→For k ≥ 4, f_k(n) ≫_k n². There exists a constant c > 0 such that for all
    36→sufficiently large n, there exists a k-critical graph on n vertices with at
    37→least c · n² edges.
    38→
    39→Proved by Toft [To70].
    40→-/
    41→theorem erdos_problem_917_part1 (k : ℕ) (hk : k ≥ 4) :
    42→    ∃ c : ℝ, c > 0 ∧ ∃ N₀ : ℕ, ∀ n : ℕ, n ≥ N₀ →
    43→      ∃ G : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
    44→        G.IsCritical k ∧ (G.edgeSet.ncard : ℝ) ≥ c * (n : ℝ) ^ 2 :=
    45→  sorry
    46→
    47→/--
    48→Erdős Problem #917, Part 2 [Er69b][Er93]:
    49→f₆(n) ∼ n²/4. For all ε > 0 and sufficiently large n, the maximum number of
    50→edges in a 6-critical graph on n vertices is asymptotically n²/4.
    51→-/
    52→theorem erdos_problem_917_part2 :
    53→    ∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 → ∃ N₀ : ℕ, ∀ n : ℕ, n ≥ N₀ →
    54→      (∃ G : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
    55→        G.IsCritical 6 ∧ (G.edgeSet.ncard : ℝ) ≥ (1 / 4 - ε) * (n : ℝ) ^ 2) ∧
    56→      (∀ G : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
    57→        G.IsCritical 6 → (G.edgeSet.ncard : ℝ) ≤ (1 / 4 + ε) * (n : ℝ) ^ 2) :=
    58→  sorry
    59→
    60→/--
    61→Erdős Problem #917, Part 3 [Er69b]:
    62→For k ≥ 6, f_k(n) ∼ (1/2)(1 - 1/⌊k/3⌋) n².
    63→
    64→Note: Disproved by Stiebitz [St87] for k ≢ 0 (mod 3).
    65→-/
    66→theorem erdos_problem_917_part3 (k : ℕ) (hk : k ≥ 6) :
    67→    let d : ℕ := k / 3
    68→    let α : ℝ := 1 / 2 * (1 - 1 / (d : ℝ))
    69→    ∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 → ∃ N₀ : ℕ, ∀ n : ℕ, n ≥ N₀ →
    70→      (∃ G : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
    71→        G.IsCritical k ∧ (G.edgeSet.ncard : ℝ) ≥ (α - ε) * (n : ℝ) ^ 2) ∧
    72→      (∀ G : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
    73→        G.IsCritical k → (G.edgeSet.ncard : ℝ) ≤ (α + ε) * (n : ℝ) ^ 2) :=
    74→  sorry
    75→

1→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Coloring
     3→import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Ordinal
     4→import Mathlib.SetTheory.Ordinal.Arithmetic
     5→import Mathlib.Order.RelClasses
     6→
     7→open SimpleGraph Cardinal Ordinal
     8→
     9→noncomputable section
    10→
    11→/-!
    12→# Erdős Problem #919
    13→
    14→Is there a graph $G$ with vertex set $\omega_2^2$ and chromatic number $\aleph_2$
    15→such that every subgraph whose vertices have a lesser type has chromatic number
    16→$\leq \aleph_0$?
    17→
    18→What if instead we ask for $G$ to have chromatic number $\aleph_1$?
    19→
    20→This question was inspired by a theorem of Babai, that if $G$ is a graph on a
    21→well-ordered set with chromatic number $\geq \aleph_0$ there is a subgraph on
    22→vertices with order-type $\omega$ with chromatic number $\aleph_0$.
    23→
    24→Erdős and Hajnal showed this does not generalise to higher cardinals — they
    25→constructed a graph on $\omega_1^2$ with chromatic number $\aleph_1$ such that
    26→every strictly smaller subgraph has chromatic number $\leq \aleph_0$.
    27→
    28→A similar construction produces a graph on $\omega_2^2$ with chromatic number
    29→$\aleph_2$ such that every smaller subgraph has chromatic number $\leq \aleph_1$.
    30→
    31→https://www.erdosproblems.com/919
    32→Tags: graph theory, chromatic number
    33→-/
    34→
    35→/--
    36→Erdős Problem #919, Part 1 [Er69b]:
    37→
    38→Is there a graph on a well-ordered set of order type ω₂ · ω₂ with chromatic
    39→number ℵ₂ such that every subgraph induced on a subset of strictly smaller
    40→order type has chromatic number ≤ ℵ₀?
    41→
    42→The chromatic number condition is expressed as: any proper coloring of G
    43→requires at least ℵ₂ colors, while every induced subgraph on a subset of
    44→smaller order type admits a proper coloring with countably many (ℕ) colors.
    45→-/
    46→theorem erdos_problem_919_part1 :
    47→    ∃ (V : Type) (_ : LinearOrder V) (_ : IsWellOrder V (· < ·))
    48→      (G : SimpleGraph V),
    49→      -- The order type of V is ω₂ · ω₂
    50→      Ordinal.type ((· < ·) : V → V → Prop) =
    51→        Cardinal.ord (aleph 2) * Cardinal.ord (aleph 2) ∧
    52→      -- G has chromatic number ≥ ℵ₂ (any proper coloring needs ≥ ℵ₂ colors)
    53→      (∀ (α : Type), Nonempty (G.Coloring α) → aleph 2 ≤ #α) ∧
    54→      -- Every induced subgraph on a subset of smaller order type is
    55→      -- countably colorable
    56→      (∀ (S : Set V),
    57→        Ordinal.type (Subrel (· < ·) S) <
    58→          Cardinal.ord (aleph 2) * Cardinal.ord (aleph 2) →
    59→        Nonempty ((G.induce S).Coloring ℕ)) :=
    60→  sorry
    61→
    62→/--
    63→Erdős Problem #919, Part 2 [Er69b]:
    64→
    65→What if instead we ask for G to have chromatic number ℵ₁?
    66→
    67→Is there a graph on a well-ordered set of order type ω₂ · ω₂ with chromatic
    68→number exactly ℵ₁ such that every subgraph induced on a subset of strictly
    69→smaller order type has chromatic number ≤ ℵ₀?
    70→-/
    71→theorem erdos_problem_919_part2 :
    72→    ∃ (V : Type) (_ : LinearOrder V) (_ : IsWellOrder V (· < ·))
    73→      (G : SimpleGraph V),
    74→      -- The order type of V is ω₂ · ω₂
    75→      Ordinal.type ((· < ·) : V → V → Prop) =
    76→        Cardinal.ord (aleph 2) * Cardinal.ord (aleph 2) ∧
    77→      -- G has chromatic number exactly ℵ₁:
    78→      -- any proper coloring needs ≥ ℵ₁ colors
    79→      (∀ (α : Type), Nonempty (G.Coloring α) → aleph 1 ≤ #α) ∧
    80→      -- and G is ℵ₁-colorable
    81→      (∃ (α : Type), #α ≤ aleph 1 ∧ Nonempty (G.Coloring α)) ∧
    82→      -- Every induced subgraph on a subset of smaller order type is
    83→      -- countably colorable
    84→      (∀ (S : Set V),
    85→        Ordinal.type (Subrel (· < ·) S) <
    86→          Cardinal.ord (aleph 2) * Cardinal.ord (aleph 2) →
    87→        Nonempty ((G.induce S).Coloring ℕ)) :=
    88→  sorry
    89→
    90→end
    91→
